name: POSTAL 2
description: Live a week in the life of "The Postal Dude"; a hapless everyman just trying to check off some chores. Buying milk, returning an overdue library book, getting Gary Coleman's autograph, what could possibly go wrong?

reviews.review_text: Offensive, stupid, annoying, gross, and a waste of your time.  Go buy it now.

'Until someone boxes up syphilis and tries to sell it at retail, Postal 2 is the worst product ever foisted upon consumers.' - Computer Gaming World 0/10  'Including a coin-op arcade game called 'F-A-G Hunter' in the game world is not only not funny, it's disgusting and hateful.' -GMR Magazine. 0/10  'Strings together a bunch of violent novelties without ever constructing a compelling game for them to support.' -GameSpot 4.8/10  'Vulgarity doesn't make Postal a particularly bad game. Postal makes Postal a bad game. Flawed from the start, being crude for the sake of being crude makes it lame, but playing it makes it a pain. Ten editors walked by to read the billboards and see the gags on my screen and simply frowned while letting out a unanimous, 'Is that supposed to be funny?' '. -IGN 5.5/10   Don't get intimated by the 'professional' reviewers and the Metacritic score. This game is a definite must buy, in fact you must buy this game now. It's definitely worth your time and money. But don't buy Postal 3, it's a hunk of junk. Buy Postal 2 along with Postal 1 for the best experience possible.

One of the most bizarre and controversial titles of the early 2000s is back and it’s found its way onto STEAM. Postal 2 Complete has been greenlit by the community, which either means that its now better than ever or that we’ve all completely lost our minds.  After playing the game again, it would seem as though the latter is true.  In Postal 2, you are given a number of errands that you must complete each day. While the errands are similar to what most of us would call “missions”, their objectives are often much more simple than the missions we’ve become accustomed to in RPGs and other titles. In a testament to this, one of the first errands you have to run is to go to the store and get some milk. The atmosphere of the store is hilarious, as the middle eastern music blasts and the shopkeeper insults all of the patrons in his shop. The brilliance of Postal 2 is the non-linear manner in which you can complete your errands. Do you just pay for the milk or do you just grab it and then fight your way out of the store, hitting everyone in your path with a shovel? The choice is yours. I should warn you though, the shop keeper is packing serious heat.
Everything is on fire and stained with my urine.  10/10

You know those stupid overhyped news stories about how violent video games are negatively affecting today’s youth? This is exactly the kind of game that they’re afraid of. However, if you have any common sense (and a sense of humor) it’s pretty clear that Postal 2 is simply a satire of American paranoia and ignorance. You play as the Postal Dude, aiding him as he completes a list of tasks over the course of a week. As you go about your business, you’ll notice increasingly crazy things happening all around you, such as anti-violent video game protestors who seem to love trying to kill you, trigger-happy police officers, hillbillies who apparently love the movie “Deliverance”, and more. It’s all very ridiculous and over the top, but that’s exactly the point.   Postal 2 is crude, extremely violent, outrageous, and lots of fun. Avoid if you’re easily offended. Otherwise, go postal.

The most artistic indie game I've ever played. In Postal 2, you must resist the urge to be a terrible person in a world that mirror's our own. Guns are everywhere in Arizona, and everyone carries them because of the damned Republicans and their concealed carry laws. The game shows you what can go wrong in such a society, as things get progressively worse every day.   It's also a pretty good simulation of life. You can pee in the toilets, (can't flush them though, no use key). You can collect stray cats and deposit them in safe places, You can also find tanks of gasoline and fuel up people's cars. Neat! You can do almost anything your imagination can think of!

I was honestly scared that this game would suck (the 'Proffesional' critics said it did) but I have to say I love this game, and I don't regret buying it at all. The game is of course offensive, but it's very funny, and even though on the surface it may appear to be offensive for shock value, there are actually messages and commentary behind the very offensive stuff (for the most part.) Postal 2 is funny, however, for more than scripted scenes; the random shenanigans that can happen in the open world can be quite amusing and fun to watch, especially doing something like kicking someone, having them pull a gun on you, then have them (and possibly the whole town) get into a fire-fight with the police. The story in Postal obviously isn't the important part, it's simply a big fetch quest around the town of paradise, however it's not hard get lost on the way there, as it's easy to get caught up in the fun of slaughtering people. The game has a wide selection of weapons, which makes attacking random civs and police interesting. Some weapons such as the pistol, baton, shotgun, and assult rifle are common, while some are area specific, rare, and for the most part more interesting. You can get an axe to hack at peoples limbs. If they survive a hit to the arm, they run around screaming until you finish them. Or how about a can of gasoline, to light anyone you want on fire? Burning someone causes them to run around in circles, igniting anyone or anything they touch, eventually (unless killed or extinguished first) they collapse in a pile of searing charred flesh, barely clinging to life, free to be kicked to death as you please. But the best weapon in the game is one you start with: urine. The ability to ♥♥♥♥ on people, believe it or not, is one of the most powerful weapos, as it causes people to stop what they're doing and rub their face. Or, if you get lucky, they might puke and completely stand still for 5 seconds or so, leaving you plenty of time to kill them. Postal's gore is awesome, and with so many varied ways to kill (My favorite is hacking all of someone's limbs off, burning them to a crisp, then as they beg for you to end it, kick them until they explode) you never feel bored travelling between areas. Definetly ignore whatever stupid 0/10 reviews you see, this game is awesome! Oh, and it's still getting updates, which means you can bet on even more cool content coming.

I beg to you, DO NOT underestimate this game. People call it ''Boring'', because they probably not have finished the first three objectives. The people who find it ''Offensive'', may or may not know it's a comedy/satire, and take everything personally. The ''Gross-Out Humor'', is not as common as critics exaggerate.   After the previous game where he kills everyone in town,''Postal Dude'' moves to Paradise, Arizona with his darling morbidly obese wife. The only problem I had with this is that in the ending of Postal 1, has The Postal Dude get a psychological breakdown, then end up in a mental hospital. Everything about that is forgotton. Anyways, The Dude's wife nags him to do common errands, like buying some milk from a ethnic store. There are many outcomes to this.  1.Buy the milk like a legal individual, and get insulted for being, ''unclean''. 2.Shoplift the milk, which activates security, and fight Habib and the terrorists in the building. 3.Get the milk, and kill everyone. 4.Shoplift the milk, and find a secret underground area where mutant dogs try to kill you. 5.Shoplift the milk, run upstairs and break through the window like a badass.  Of course, the law enforcment can arrest you for being a Maniac. You Could:  A: Kill him. B: Bribe him. C: Accept your arrest. D: Run away. E: Stand there like an idiot and get killed.  Your actions have consequences, so be wise before ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ everywhere.  There are more than ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ and cussing, so give this game a try.  Don't trust the overly harsh reviews from know-it-all professional game critics, if you like social/political satire, GO BUY NOW, YOU MIGHT BE DIE BEFORE YOU KNOW IT. That is all.

This is a great game for anyone looking to blow off some Steam (pun intended).   Released back in 2003 it still holds up after 12 years, both gameplay and entertainment wise. Postal 2 actually supersedes a lot of current releases when it comes to it's fluid physics for water, gasoline and even the p-i-s-s physics.   The Steam version of Postal 2 includes the core game of Postal 2, Postal 2: Share The Pain (The Multiplayer Component), Postal 2: Apocalypse Weekend (an expansion pack for the original Postal 2 released back in 2005 which adds Sunday and Saturday), and finally Postal 2: A Week in Paradise (A mod developed by Resurrection Studios which adds the ability to play through both the core game of Postal 2 and Apocalypse Weekend in one sitting, with additional weapons such as the Chainsaw).  If you want the Eternal Damnation mod you will either have to pick up The Fudge Pack (which also includes Postal 1, and other additional content like game trailers released prior E3), or download it for free and install it as an addon for your Postal 2 Steam Version of the game. This also doesn't include Akella's officially unofficial Штопор Жжот addon released back in 2005.  Share The Pain could USE some (a lot actually) updates, it doesn't seem it has been updated ever since it's release as freeware in 2008; resulting in terrible connection problems, frequent disconnects, and barren list of servers. But Postal 2 is all about the Singleplayer experience, however, a mod or an expension implementing Co-Op would be a long-awaited and a welcome feature, allowing you to play the entire week with your friends would be a blast and add a lot of hours to anyone's playthroughs with additional replayabilty value to it's Singleplayer 'campaign'.  The game overall runs at a steady framerate, whether you're playing it on a PC or a Mac. The only issues I had were some hard crashes of the game due to some missions getting stuck and the entire Steam client crashing - but with constant auto-saving this isn't a big issue.   Overall, this is a great game and still gives me a massive nostalgia boost.

POSTAL 2 is the most crude and offensive game I've ever played. It's very likely that it will always be that way, as no other developer has the balls to create such a piece of video game putrefaction. Its entire existence is solely based on enduring some of the most politically incorrect, disgusting, and shocking scenes ever programmed. As you should expect, it's a comedy game that doesn't really give a ♥♥♥♥ about its 'videogameness'. Nearly 100% of the development was spent on the shocking comedy aspect, and not much on gameplay. Typically, I do not enjoy those types of games, as I prefer my comedy games to at least still be a good game. But POSTAL 2, gameplay wise, only fails in a few areas.  In terms of open world exploration, scripted events, environments, and basically everything that makes a great open world game, POSTAL 2 excels extraordinarily. However, in terms of FPS mechanics... POSTAL 2 is severely lacking. Hitboxes are jacked up, weapons are unbalanced, everything is just a mess. It isn't too bothersome, but still one of the things that wounds this game from being taken seriously.  POSTAL 2 also has a large amount of typical gameplay bugs... but it seems that RWS wants it this way. I mean, after nearly 13 years of semi-consistent updates and rereleases, you would have expected them to fix it, right? Admittedly, these bugs are sort of funny when they happen, and they do give somewhat of a replay factor, but there's no excuse for poor game design.  Speaking of replay ability, this game has loads of it. It features an absurd amount of difficulties, different ways to complete missions, large open world environments, lots and lots of secrets and easter eggs, 88 clever achievements, and much more.  If you play through the full game, there are 7 days. Unfortunately, POSTAL 2 loses steam on the 6th day. What made the first 5 days great was the hilarious jokes, open world, everything that I previously mentioned. But on the 6th and 7th days, it's like they gave up and just put in a bunch of grindy filler that isn't really that funny or rewarding, it just makes you want to finally complete the game.  Overall, I had and will continue to have a lot of fun playing POSTAL 2, but as a game it isn't too great. The amount you will enjoy this game really varies on your video game preferences. I recommend it, but take causion, as it might not be for you.  6/10 - Good

Alright, so straight off the bat, when you start up the game, it warns you not to play it if you're young, disgusted by violence in general, or plan to take a career in politics. Let's just say that if you wanna run for governor, don't be surprised if you're kicked out of the state. Or shot ironically.   Getting that out of the way, POSTAL 2 takes place in sunny, desert wasteland Paradise, Arizona. You can tell they did their research because half of the video game self-inserts have huge machineguns carried around wherever they walk, just like in America. You play as a pessimistic delivery man who only finds comfort in his dog because his wife is a disembodied voice, unless you buy Paradise Lost. Now, as soon as you get kicking, its clear that the game is that of a magnum opus level, you have so much freedom of choice straight off the bat. You can invade the neighbor's house in front of you, pick up a shovel, you can hit your dog, your only friend, you can use the restrooms outdoors, it's quite a scene to behold.   Unfortunately, because Postal 2 was made a decade ago, you cannot complain about the subpar graphics because it doesn't make sense, you graphic obsessed dog-hater. The vulgarity in the game is also pretty unsettling to those who get their underwear twisted in the wash easily, being the oblivious person I am, I accidentally bumped into a woman who yelled, 'Look out' at my face. Such rudeness! I only slammed into her at walking speed on accident!   But in conclusion, I have to say that while somewhat disturbing to play, that is, if you have the sanity level of a horror game character in the dark, it's good, clean, bloody, morbidly humorous fun. I highly recommend it to anyone who does not own a firearm in real life, and slightly less but still recommend it for its fun to any triggerhappy gun enthusiast who likes practicing in shooting ranges on the weekend.

Another game that would really benefit from a 'mixed' recommendation.   This is a hard game to rate, because it's based on the player more than the game. But there is a game behind it that needs to be reviewed.  So the game is an old 13 year old game (released in 2003 so the future people have the actual time scale). When Postal was popular with the mass murdering gameplay, Running With Scisssors worked on a sequel, and took their time, 6 years later, Postal 2 came out, and it's certainly different.   3d graphics versus an isometric game, story instead of random murder, and actually a very different tone as well.   The problem is similar to other games it hasn't aged amazing. 13 year old 3d technology is quite interesting to see. At the same time, Postal 2 is unlike any other game, and that's both a positive and a negative.   Postal 2 tries very hard to be edgy, but it does so in a way that definitely makes it almost a time capsule. Putting muslim suicide bombers in the game in 2003, was extremely tasteless, now... Not as much? Osama Bin Laden's name is in the game, is that edgy any more? Shooting bullets through cats (in oddly enough not as tasteless a way as someone would do now)   I think a majority of the humor of the game has actually fallen away. I mean there's a voting joke and it's referencing the 2000 election... It's actually a little funny, but that's one kind of humor you're going to get. The other? Well there's a way to pee on, anyone you want. You have a very juvenile humor in this game, and yet it kind of works on some level.   The thing is the entire game tries VERY hard to be edgy, so if you can be offended, you will be. Almost every woman is big breasted, and I don't mean 'there's a lot of Buxom characters'. No, there's like ONE female player model and it's a big breasted woman, there's two males that I noticed, a skinny and a fat guy. If that's going to offend you you're going to get ♥♥♥♥♥♥. The only Muslims in the game are the terrorists/taliban who will attack you on sight, if you're going to be offended, you'll have a problem. The list goes on. If you can get offended, this game will try to find that button.   But overall, I mean it's insults from 2003, that kind of don't hit any more. I don't know, I can't really be offended by it, because it's made to offend, not because it's an honest opinion expressing itself.   There is a bit of cognitive dissonance when you get to the trophies as they were added recently. There's numerous references to both the League and It's Always Sunny in Philadelphia as well as other recent pop culture in the trophies. It's actually a weird touch, but you know what? It kind of helps.   As for the technical parts of the game, the majority of the game works perfectly, with the exception of the sound. Ugh, the sound. I'm going to guess this was the beginning of 3d sound technology, and maybe something's changed since then, but the main character speaks VERY loud, and every other important character is near impossible to hear. A shame.  I could go into more, but honestly. If you want to see what got a lot of people's panties in a bunch in 2003 this is a perfect game for that. It's not an amazing game, it's not going to blow you away. This isn't going down in the hall of fame of gaming (except for its attempt at offensiveness) but I've played a lot of worse games, and Postal 2 seems to understand it's not a top tier game and has priced themselves at a realistic number.   Overall there's a game that works well (though I did see a few crashes). It's both incredibly playable and interactive. It actually has a lot of choice involved in it (you can beat the game without killing anyone or ignore the story and go on a murder rampage, the game allows both options). And with the exception of the sound issue that was an annoyance, it's still a solid game.   If you're unsure, I would probably not recommend the game, but for what it is, it's a positive gaming experience. Just be sure you know what you're getting into and aren't going to get offended by 13 year old jokes (that are probably also aimed at 13 year olds)

Postal 2 - is a First Person open world action game which has very dark humor and very high octane game play .  From start to finish the game is just fun , the level of enjoyment seems to be reached by comedic plot lines in the story or just bizarre behavior from the world and its inhabitants .   Postal 2 - Paradise Lost DLC - Ive never played a dlc for a game like this , its generally classed as the sequel to postal 2 and until you start to play u wont understand why considering there is a Postal 3 ( which the devs 'running with scissors' co-developed with another company and didn't hit the same feel as previous games ) , the dlc is like a whole new game not just an addon with a few tweaks. The map and the game engine haven't changed drastically but its enough to make u feel like its worth while. Definitely a must own for those who completed and enjoyed Postal 2.  Downside to Postal 2 and the DLC - has to be that there are a lot of loading scenes in between parts of the town which the game makes you go back and forth between regularly . A few bugs but nothing game breaking (there was a game breaking bug due to the Halloween 2016 update but the Dev was vocal on the steam forum post and fixed it promptly)

I bought this game in like 2004, but I figured I'd post a review anyway. This game is pretty awesome the first time you play it. I personally like to pee on peoples' faces, and then douse them with gasoline and light them on fire while they're puking. Chopping people up is fun too. My only complaints worth mentioning are that there is only a somewhat small assortment of weapons and, thus limited ways to kill people. Having something that could disembowel someone woulda been fun, for instance. I could think of other ways to kill that'd be cool, but you get the point. Also, being able to torture people in different ways would have been a good addition. I wish violent games on the whole would get just a bit more nasty. This game has the right idea. Again, just wish there was a much larger variety of nasty stuff you could do to people.

A delectably offensive game where you have the freedom to run errands for your unappreciative wife like a good middle-class American... or you could slaughter countless civilians for no other reason than because you ♥♥♥♥ing can. You can explore a large-ish world full of delightfully crazy townsfolk, marching bands, Gary Coleman, zombies, and the Taliban, of course, and you'll find tons of normal and not-so normal weapons with which to dispense your rage. From shovels and scissors to boomerang machetes and anthrax-filled cow heads, the possibilities are plentiful. The graphics are quite dated, but the gameplay and ridiculous humor more than make up for it. To top it all off, you've got surprisingly fun multiplayer and the game is still being updated by the original developers. They even released a brand new expansion pack in April continuing the story of the Postal Dude after his odd adventures in Postal III. Overall a must-buy and definitely the best in the series.

10 years after i first purchased a copy of Postal 2 on disc i decided to buy it again this time through steam just for the nostalgia but i got slightly more than i bargained for with my £1.79 First off, even after 10 years the developers decided to update the game and make a bunch of fixes that even after all this time i could notice, a few new weapons and some extra additions i thought were a very nice touch especially considering the age of this game. First off you are the the 'Postal Dude' and you are trying to survive your week either monday to friday in the standard game, Apocalyspe Weekend which as it states covers saturday and sunday or play through the entire week Monday through Sunday. Mad cap missions and politically incorrect everything make this game a classic, in comparison it makes Duke Nukem look like a Disney tale. Shoddy graphics and physics aside this is not for the serious gamer, it is purely here to mock everything we know and just be as distasteful as possible, and boy they do a good job! From Neo Nazi like cops to Taliban suicide attacks this game really does have it all in terms of bad taste!   well worth playing just for the madness, utter utter madness  9/10

So I would recommend this game when it’s on sale.   Thank you for reading my view of this game and decide wisely!

A lot of my friends try to convince me to play Grand Theft Auto. I have two of the games in the series, in fact - Vice City and San Andreas. They both bore me. This game, however, has a lot of the same ideas as the GTA series, but is much more enjoyable to actually play.  You play as some guy with the most creative name ever to grace video games: 'The Postal Dude'. The way the story works is you get a list of errands each day. They sound really dull, you do each one, and once you've actually finished a task, something disastrous happens around you and you have to escape. It's quite difficult at times, while never really becoming frustrating (I play on Insane-o difficulty - this game has a bizarrely large selection of difficulty settings). It's also hilarious, but I won't spoil the jokes.  TL;DR Would annoy the protagonist of a game by saving so often again.

Well, I suppose I should start by saying that I've seen Uwe Boll's film Postal several times, and when I saw this game on sale I just had to get it. After about a month of half-hearted attempts to download it (The game is only 3 gigs, but I have limited free time and rubbish internet) I finally finished the download and decided to try it. I immediately noticed a distinct lack of subtitle options, which did not bode well as I do not live alone and correctly assumed the game would have a considerable amount of profanity. However, there have been no issues yet with the language situation. I will mention that the controls aren't always what they are supposed to be, which has caused a fair bit of confusion.  Beyond that, this game is clearly dated graphically however this does not bother me. I've never really cared about the graphics in games. The violence, while extreme for it's time is fairly unrealistic and often comical. Clearly, this isn't a game for children but parents of teenagers should not be concerned about their offspring's mental health with this game. Furthermore, it's only as violent as you want it to be. While you may have to defend yourself in certain scenarios it is entirely possible to finish the game without firing a shot in anger (or so I'm told, I only made it to Wednesday before going nuts). In fact, a good part of the fun for me was trying to stay peaceful in a crazy world. Now, I've only made it to Thursday's first task so I don't know how insane it gets but it's been rather enjoyable so far.  Every single review mentions the cat silencer (but neglects to state that it's only for your shotgun) and your ability to urinate on people at will. I was also fond of the ability to show my character's genitals to random women, that was a safe way to unleash one's inner flasher. There are also 'health pipes' to smoke and plenty of fast food to eat.  So, in conclusion it's a cheap bit of fun for those who don't take life too seriously. Or fans of Uwe Boll, as his film Postal is absolutely bonkers and not too far off from the stuff in this game.  (Edit: Meant to change this ages ago. The cat silencer can be used on the assault rifle, but as it fires so quickly it's useless.)

Postal 2 is a dated, but still extremely fun game. Although it came out in 2003 I believe, I still enjoy it nowadays. Basically you try to go through your day (each level is a day, the whole game is a week) without going insane. You'll be standing in line at the bank to get your paycheck cashed, when some guy cuts you in line. You cut him back and everyone starts to yell at you and call you names. The teller refuses to serve you. In response you pull out a can of kerosene, douse the teller, throw a match on her, watch her run around screaming until she collapses, crawling on the ground. You then unzip your pants and proceed to urinate all over her, before equipping your trusty shovel and chopping her head off. If you are easily offended, this game is not for you. Also, Running With Scissors has mentioned making a TRUE Postal sequel (Postal 3 was made by a Russian company, and it isn't fun), and buying Postal 2 on Steam helps them get the money to do so. So please buy it! Overall, the graphics are poor for today's standards, the gameplay is fun (but the gunplay feels dated), the story is WHO CARES, and the game is easy to run on any computer. 7.5 / 10

Действие игры происходит в американском городке Парадиз. Postal 2, years after its original release, is still one of my favorite games. I should explain that at the time it came out, my sophomoric potty-mouthed sense of humor had more to do with me enjoying the game than anything else. The long load screens, the buggyness, the getting stuck in certain places all the time; these did little to hinder my enjoyment of running around and peeing in peoples faces while I kicked them.   Seriously, who couldn't find that funny? Anyway, Vince Desi has made several points about the game and there's a reason it has such a huge cult following. I did eventually play the game in a challenging mode and it was, indeed, rather hard. You could play the game from beginning to end without killing a single person, and the fact that there were cheat codes built in to it were what made it fun. There, I said it. This is one of those games where the cheat codes can make a game incredibly fun, not necessarily to help you complete the game in a 'fair' manner, but to see everything that the game can do.   My sophomoric sense of humor came rushing back the minute I re-purchased (being the second copy I've owned, only this time with all the expansions) and started playing the game again. I had forgotten about some of the over-the-top action that the game provided.   That being said, I don't want anyone to think that I don't realize the glaring issues with the game. It wasn't necessarily the prettiest game, but it has aged well in comparison to some others. The voice acting in parts was terrible, probably on purpose, and the situations are ludicrous. Not that this is necessarily a bad thing, and again, this could've all been done on purpose. My biggest issue is with all the friggin' loading screens. Even with those, it doesn't take away from what the whole point of this game and this series is about: you can be the good guy or the bad guy. You can be innocent in the face of corrupt police, jerkwad store owners, and generally stupid street people that think they're 'cool' - and live out your life in relative obscurity - or you can be the alpha-jerk who pees all over the place and kills people with a shovel. Or a shotgun. You know, whatever.  I would absolutely recommend this game, RWS deserves support and praise if not for just keeping the spirit of free speech alive. Now go and buy the game, go to the RWS website and buy the merchandise, and have a damn good time while you do it. Oh, and skip over Postal III until RWS decides to do a sequal their way.   7.5/10  Note that my score is based in relation to my personal feelings on the game, I love it! I would give it more if not for the constant load screens and crashes that are suffered every couple of hours, which causes you to save your game over and over again.   Any points taken away are not for the vulgarity, the hilarity, or the overall unrealistic silliness of the game. Ignoring the problems which is easy to do because I LOVE this game, I personally give it top-10 status in my list of favorite video games of all time. It just came about at the right time in my life, and has continued to be a part of it. A small part of my personal history, and I love it for that. Being offensive for the hell of it is not at all something that is lost on me. Bananas, completely bananas.

EDIT: Very very recently, as in within the last month, the linux version of this game was patched and is now at the same version as Windows with the DLC and steam workshop integration. Only took 2 ♥♥♥♥ing years. My only problem with this game is no longer valid so I now recommend it.  The game is bad ♥♥♥♥ing ♥♥♥ and truly one of the most legendary guilty pleasure video games of all time.  The lack of recommendation though comes from being a linux user and has nothing to do with the actual game.  The problem is RWS has been promising for almost two full years now that steam workshop integration, updates, and achievements would be coming to the linux version, and none of these things have materialized. It's sad that a company that outwardly touts their linux support and how committed they are to their linux fanbase can't even get some basic hooks implemented to unlock steam achievements. Time and time again linux has been ignored by RWS with the promise that 'soon' everything will be different and it never has been. The linux port is functional but it has bugs here or there which will probably never be patched, and it's just sad to see a company that was dedicated to linux when NOBODY else in the gaming world was, eventually end up treating a big chunk of its core fanbase like trash. For that, I do not recommend it.

Live a week in the life of 'The Postal Dude'; a hapless everyman just trying to check off some chores. Buying milk, returning an overdue library book, getting Gary Coleman's autograph, what could possibly go wrong?   Blast, chop and ♥♥♥♥ your way through a freakshow of American caricatures in this darkly humorous first-person adventure. Meet Krotchy: the toy mascot gone bad, visit your Uncle Dave at his besieged religious cult compound and battle sewer-dwelling Taliban when you least expect them! Endure the sphincter-clenching challenge of cannibal rednecks, corrupt cops and berserker elephants. Accompanied by Champ, the Dude's semi-loyal pitbull, battle your way through open environments populated with amazingly unpredictable AI. Utilize an arsenal of weapons ranging from a humble shovel to a uniquely hilarious rocket launcher.   Collect a pack of attack dogs! Use cats as silencers! ♥♥♥♥ and pour gasoline on anything and everyone! YOU KNOW YOU WANT TO!

This game is just bad. In every concievable way.   - No game this vapid and this low on content which was updated in 2015 has any business looking this bad.  - The gun mechanics are questionable at best. - The baseless violence and vulgarity seems to be solely for shock value and for its own sake, and much of it seems ridiculous. - There's an irritating constant humming sound, similar to that given off by an industrial fan. - Animation is of poor quality. - Sounds are old and outdated, and this shows in their poor quality. - A loading zone for every small region even in spite of the recent updates which could have changed that makes the game feel clunky and makes exploration tedious. - A lack of meaningful storyline gives the player cause to question, 'What even is the point,' when playing. Even in a game which doesn't focus on story, that's not a good thing. - The 'humour' in the game isn't clever, instead adopting a more South Park style of shock comedy and raw vulgarity.  Overall, it feels like the video game equivalent of a poorly written episode of South Park, and is something I just want to forget. If possible, I am going to attempt to get my money back for this, but this may be difficult since I put five hours into the game hoping it would get good at some point. It never did. While I can see why someone might enjoy this game, I did not, and I do not recommend this game to anyone looking for a halfway decent gaming experience. I might recommend it to someone looking for pointless and poorly rendered violence and vulgarity. I paid 69p for this, and still feel a little ripped off.

What do you make of the kind of person who gifts you this?  A shamelessly awful game, and a controversial one from back in the day when Saddam Hussein, Osama Bin Laden, and Gary Coleman were still alive, and Jack Thompson wasn't barred from law. There is basically no plot to this game; you are just some schmuck living in a trailer park (read: behind a house) with who I thought was his mom at first, is actually his wife, and every day of the week, you're sent out to run some errands in a town filled with people seconds away from losing their minds (and who can blame them!?). Naturally, your daily errands become a slog through hell as one catastrophe stacks on another, and the end of the week ends with the apocalypse and an attempted suicide. I am referring to the Postal Dude, not myself.  The humor in this is as low as the brow gets, trying to be as offensively bad as possible with a particular obsession with Joe Liebermann and Gary Coleman. Even the kid who laughs at every fart jokes will be turned off by this. The best the humor gets is when you're running through the park, trying to find a Christmas tree, and after rejecting every tree for one reason or another all the way to the end, the perfect tree is highlighted by a god ray, cue the choir of angels. It was hardly worth the price of admission.  On top of the awfulness of the game itself, this is also a badly optimized port (though I do not blame the people who worked to add this on Steam). However, unlike most poorly optimized ports, this one will run about as fast as your computer can manage, and there is no way to tell the game to ease up on the throttle. This bleeds into cutscenes where characters will vomit out all their lines right at the very beginning before the animation can catch up. When it comes to the controls, it feels like you're trying to control a rocket-powered zamboni. You never feel truly in control, and will zoom about the map like a Benny Hill chase montage gone horribly wrong. The only way to get the game to slow down is to use a program to force your computer to operate with essentially one hand tied behind its back, but it's an unacceptable solution. For those of you who aren't experienced with overclocking, proceed at your own risk.  It's a bit cliche for the title, but this is obviously one of the games to steer clear of. Not just because of the substance, but because of the style. It fails to impress in both, it was made that way, but just because that was the intention doesn't mean it's good. Don't even send this as a prank to a friend. It will send all the wrong messages about yourself.  Just no.

postal 2 is a gam similar to the games you would play on newgrounds in the summer of 2004 except instead of being a mindless murder/torture similatro, it gives players a very odd array of unconventional weaponry and lets them explore a world of unlikable characters with targets literally painted on their backs. what happesn enxt can only be described as every soccer mom's worst nightmare come t o life.   postal 2 is developed by RWS, devleopers whose original claim to fame was children's games, before a title dropped in 1997 known only as 'postal', an isometric shooter wiht the goal 'kill everybody'. as you can imagine, the game went over as well as any game who gives the player the objective to kill elementary school children. postal 2 is a departure from the disturbing, psychotic, low-budget slaughterfest of postal 1 but it still managed to attract enough, if not more controversy than the original.   the player assumes the role of the postal dude (his real name) as he goes abotu his day completing menial tasks such as returning library books or picking up a carton of milk. however, the game's tagline 'it's only as violent as you are' is a bit misleading as mosto f these 'menial tasks' eventually devolve into hectic shootouts usually over small or unnecessary reasons. itsn early impossible to complete the gaem without killing anybodybecaus the game usually forces you into very heated firefights with no real means of getting around hostile individuals.   still, if anything can be taken from this, you can draw a parallel between the hyperviolent world of postal 2 and the average ocnsumer in a world where violence seems normal and portrayed as regular or necesssary. maybe as a means of trying to compare the npcs inhabiting paradise as amrericans or trather caricatures of americans who feel the need to attack or ruin anything they find violent, by using violence. from a rhetoric standpoint, postal 2 is very deserving of analysis and a very srong contender for the 'ivdeo games as art' argument.   that might seem silly from a game that allows you to attach cats to weapons as silencers or set people on fire and watch them burn to death while you ♥♥♥♥ on them and dismember each of their limbs one by one. however, this migth bring about an even better discussion topic: when is killing ever humane? in war? postal 2's streets are battleifelds and everybody is out to get you. does it matter whether you use an assualt rifle or a scythe? when is killing justified?   postal 2 is very dreary with the world caught in a perpetual limbo of sunset and denizens who ecxist only to make your life a tiny bit harder. unlike its predecessor, postal 2 is an fps game. for 2003, the graphics are low quality but passable. there are tiny details included taht cement the sequel as polished (at least in compariosn to the first). music barely exists, save for nightclubs, store bgm, and general ambience. the arsenal is varied enough to surprise traditional fps fans and win over the hearts of oldschool fps fanatics.   is psotal 2 disgusting? yes. is postal 2 offensive? of course. is postal 2 distasteful? absolutely. is postal 2 a good game? yes.   8/8 its pretty great.

Postal 2, more boring than shocking, but I think that 12-15 year old me would have loved this game.   All of postal 2's gimmicks seem centered around shocking people. It's as if again, a teenager, was put in a room and told to write something that would upset people. Unfortunately all of their attempts fell flat, at most getting a small 'heh' out of me for their effort at making a joke. I wasn't offended, I was annoyed with crap gameplay and repetitive scenarios.   Each day of the week you're given three tasks to complete. Usually something goes wrong and you're forced to use force to escape, or it's just easier to blast your way through than to do it the 'nice' way. I suppose if you want to you can kill random people by a number of ways and then ♥♥♥♥ on their corpses afterwards. I'll give Postal 2 credit for being unique, but after seeing these gimmicks one time, they're boring.  I only made it halfway through Thursday (game goes till Friday and has a weekend for the new DLC) when I decided I couldn't take the terrible gunplay and boring walking from place to place anymore. Engaging people in the streets was a waste of ammo and time. In games like GTA5 or saints row, I would hear someone say something, beat them up, or shoot them feeling a little satisfied. Then get chased by the cops. In this game I shoot a guy on the streets, then I shoot the cop right after and it ends. Nothing exciting or interesting about it (no risk or reward not even the satisfaction of 'beating' the cops).  Overall: terrible comedic writing, terrible (repetitive) gameplay, and the game wasn't even offensive (even though that's what everyone remembers it for).

You guys made a great game. Sure, it won't win any award for having gorgeous graphics and has its share amount of bugs, but its still a very enjoyable experience. The story is long enough, and has replay value. The Apocalypse Weekend fan mod that is bundled with the gamr will also extend your experience, even though it's not as replayable as the first 5 days of the week. Workshop support will also extend the life of the game, thus making it an excellent buy. All in all, it's a great game, but I found one flaw, this happens especially on the Apocalypse Weekend levels: The game drops FPS like it's nobody's business. Most of the time it stays way over 60 fps, but in one of the missions, it dipped so badly that the mission was unplayable without a cheat code. I'm talking FPS dips to below 3 FPS. Hopefully you can sort that out, but other than that, this game is definitely worth a play.

Ever wanted to take out your anger in the most violent way possible but felt constrained by the laws in the real world? Well now you can take out your vengence against humanity with Postal 2. With numerous weapons, endless civillians to murder, and a foul-mouthed main character who hates society as much as you do, this game is the ultimate stress releiver. But, if you prefer your games with a story and not much focus on gore, then you may be a little disappointed since this game isn't the best example for narratives. Despite the fact that Postal 2 has next to no plot other than doing a list of errands, this game is worth the money.

THE most tasteless video game that the world has ever seen, and will possibly ever likely see again. It would prove very hard to top. Definitely not a game for kids, the easily offended, or someone who doesn't laugh at bad taste, toilet humour, and gay culture. With that out of the way, Postal 2 lets you indulge in cartharsis in a way that no other game dares. On one hand it is a parody of modern day gun-toting America, on the other, a right-wing nut-job's shooting gallery, on another hand entirely, it's a test of Christian faith!  There is no plot to the game other than to do your daily chores, but the other citizens in the game have other ideas. Usually violent ones. One of the best things about this game is that while you are prodded and enticed to commit violent actions - it is never mandatory. In most scenes in the game, you can play like Ghandi and respond non-violently by running away to escape assailants and at the end of the game you are rewarded for the accomplishment. Of course with all those guns lying around, it would be a bit silly to let all that ammo and flammables go to waste.... You can dish out virtual ultra-violence on all your bigoted hatreds in one game! Just about all targets of right-wing extremist hatred are present.  Gameplay resembles grand-theft-auto, but without the ability to drive vehicles. There's plenty of variety in scenes the player is put in (the compound stand-off was genius), and the adult humour is funny the first time around at least. What's most enjoyable is watching the in-game characters fight amongst themselves. You can hit a character and run away, and they will blame someone else, and watch them get into a gunfight, which the police try to break up but also get involved in. Once enough stray bullets have flown around, more people get in on the action and so on, and so on, until it's total and utter chaos.  The grpahics are old and fairly poor, but it's probably just as well.

There are no words suitable enough to describe the sheer lunacy this game bears. It is a complete anomaly in gaming. Very few other games have even come close to matching the pure joy and laughter that this game brought to me. (intentional laughter and joy mind you) The fearless creativity and poignant satire on display in Postal 2 are executed so well in spite of it's obvious limitations. Postal 2 rightfully found it's way onto my Top 10 favorite games of all time ever since it's original release. Though obviously not intended for normal everyday gamers, especially not the easily offended by extreme violence, language, etc. But if you're bored of the middle of the road average games being highlighted by the public and you're craving for demented madness, you should definitely play this game. Including the Apocalypse Weekend and Paradise Lost expansions. We'll likely never see a game like this again.

Probably the most violent, gratuitous, blasphemous game I've ever played. And I love it all the way through. It's like playing a deranged version of Family Guy without Stewie. Postal 2 was my first ever open world(ish) game. I've played this since its release in 2003 so 99% of my hours are not logged here.  Postal is a FPS where you can be as peace loving as a hippy or as homicidal as a maniac.  You are the Postal Dude and its up to you to complete your many daily tasks. Buy milk, collect a Christmas tree, you even get Gary Coleman's autograph. What could go wrong? You start the day with the tasks marked out on the map. You can explore (robbing houses as you go if you wish) and perform your tasks in any order. The world is persistent and people go about their business without interaction from the Dude. The levels are the days of the week and on Monday you start with a lot of 'Paradise' blocked off to you. As the days progress the game opens up more and more. You can choose to play the game from Monday to Friday (the weekend came later as a thing known as an 'expansion pack' :) ) or you can play the entire week. Saturday and Sunday forego all the open world aspects in favour of linier gameplay and the events are crazy even by Postal standards.   You do have a choice of how to act but the game pushes you towards violence in an obvious fashion what with rude passers by, weapons laying around (I know this is set in America but bloody hell) and the fact that a pacifists game is a boring one. There are a huge amount of weapons ranging from petrol and match to a scythe. A lot of fun can be had killing the populous. Some will run screaming in terror, others will shoot at you and if the police catch the carnage then they will try to arrest you. Now you have choices. Run, hide and hope the police bar runs out and disappears so they stop looking for you? Bribe the officer and hope it works? Or you could take the go quietly route. You'll be taken to a cell and will have to escape. If you fail to escape (and are not horribly beaten to death) you'll be taken to another cell a higher floor up that's tougher to get out of.  As you perform tasks you'll end up getting on the wrong side of certain groups. It’s always a case of being in the wrong place at the wrong time and is really not fair on the Dude. Members of these groups will try to kill you on sight from that point on. 'Go on! Be violent! Its only defending yourself!' says the game. Another way Postal 2 steers you on the path to the dark side.  So that's it. Complete tasks to end your day and you can kill as little or as much as you like while doing it. Simple but a lot of fun. If you're one of the more shallow gamers and graphics are all you care for then don't touch this game. Postal 2 has an even more dated look than other games of its era. This is being improved slightly by the devs supporting the game (11 years later!) and updating the graphics here and there. There are many crude and hilarious moments. Nothing is to be taken seriously here but it’s the kind of humor the easily offended should stay away from. Being able to urinate on people in the context of the game is funny but it’s not for everyone. There's a ton of funny events, tasks and things you can see around Paradise and I don't want to spoil it for anyone new.  As a final note the achievements for this game are the best ever on Steam. Most of them are loads of fun to get! How about that for a novel concept? Other devs take note!

Postal II is a game I did not plan on buying. I've seen it a lot on Youtube and thought 'Hmmm, GTA in FPS mode?'. I bought this game though recently after the awesome Steam Sale (Seriously, I bought like 10 games due to this sale under 50 bucks :D), and boy, this game is just downright fun. To put it short, you are the infamous 'Postal Dude', a guy with a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ wife, a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ home, a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ life, and lives in a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ town. The objective: Do what your wife tells you to do within 1 week (Yes, the full seven days) but how YOU wanna do it. To understand what I mean by this, here is what happened when I first played: The wife wanted me to pick up so milk and collect and cash a check...I killed over 50 people, creamated 50 more, kicked some people to death, beat others with a shovel, ♥♥♥♥♥♥ on 3 cops, shoved a shotgun up a cat's butt and shot the poor ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ across a building, fought a store clerk after trying to steal some milk which lead to him pulling out an nearly killing me with an M16, AND THEN I picked up and cashed the check...then did pretty much everything I just listed above on the way home...Yea this game is ♥♥♥♥ed up at best...but in a fun way. You can play the game the way you want. Yes, you don't have to kill at all, you can live life normally and not do anything wrong...but this is almost a test of will-power since the game pretty much ENCOURAGES you to kill and do horribly funny ♥♥♥♥. Seriously, I mean when you first start the game, you find a shovel, some armor, matches, and a freaking gas tank! How could you NOT kill anybody :3?  This game does have a lot of insensitive content so buy at your risk if you get easily offending by racial stereotypes and idea's such as a freaking Homeless simulator for kids. Also, this game seems to make fun of violence in video games. It feels like the game is saying 'Screw all you people who hate violence in video games' and I....am completely okay with this. Seriously, this game is just awesome in every way for me and I love it! Honestly, this game is for those people who wanna just pull off some stress from school, work, maybe family? This is a great way to control stress for you, just go crazy and go kill people without risking you going to jail in real life and getting the death penalty. I just pray that none of you actually do this stuff in real life because trust me, if you ♥♥♥♥ on a cop, he or she is not just gonna stand there and look at you digusted and throw up...no buddy your going to jail for real so don't be an idiot and try to recreate what you see in this game for the 'Lolz'.  Now if you played the much more disturbing but not as gruesome Postal I, then you will see that this game and the first are VERY different though I still find Postal I an amazing game as well. Postal II is a dark comedy game that seems to make fun of everything while Postal I is just dark, creepy, and twisted. Here are just a little objective comparison: Postal I has you brutally murdering everybody because you have been evicted from your horrible home...that's it, there is no happy joking or funny moments...it's just dark and brutal while Postal II is the opposite in everyway except for violence (Yes, the Postal I and II story lines are completely different and not related in anyway). This game has homophobia, drugs, sex, trans, minorities who abuse their label, and ♥♥♥♥ing Gary Coleman...o and about a thousand other weird things. This game is just stupid, so freaking stupid, and that is the best part about this game. It doesn't take itself seriously like Postal I. Postal II pretty much says 'O, you killed a bunch of people and possibly ruined the lives of all their families and loved ones? Well good news! Homeless Simulator has just came to town and people wanna play it, YOU KNOW WHAT TO DO :D!'   So pick up Postal II today, seriously, you have nothing to lose. O, and multiplayer is fun, good ol' DM and the achievements are halirious and insensitive at best! O and since this is the Complete Collection, the expansion packs are included and they are fun as hell and just adds more ♥♥♥♥ for you to do. Sooooo, go Postal and start wrecking havoc! Or, if you are just Good Guy Greg, don't kill anybody and wreck ♥♥♥♥ up, just do what your wife says and go home just to have her nag at you the next day to do her differnet errands...you'll see how long you can last the week in this game before you end up going Postal....Ooo is that a shotgun over there?

Pros: - Postal Dude, - controversial humor - the game parodies Taliban, ecologists, opponents of computer games, meat factories, cash-hungry priests and much more, - a lot of weapons (and you can have them all in your inventory :D), - open world - you can enter almost every building in the game, - huge city, - cutting off limbs (every sadist will love this game :P), - you always have choise to patiently wait in line or to just kill everyone and take what's yours, - challenging police, - easter eggs, - newspapers, - the game is quite stable (unlike Postal III) - I didn't notice any major bugs and it crashed only one time, - multiplayer.  Exclusive to Steam version: - even though the game has 11 years it's still updated, - Steam Workshop, - achievements, - new options (like accesories for pedestrians or antialiasing), - two new difficulty levels, - new easter eggs (like Postal III on the junkyard :P), - Postal 2 merged with Apocalypse Weekend (just like in A Week in Paradise mod) - new weapons from Apocalypse Weekend are available in Postal 2.  Cons: - poor soundtrack, - poor cutscenes, - it takes too long to find a specific weapon if you have full inventory what often results in death, - Apocalypse Weekend is very linear, - Taliban training camp and military base in Apocalypse Weekend are way too long and boring, - there aren't any languages different than English in Steam version (it's easy to copy translated files from boxed version but first you need to buy boxed version).  I have a lot of fun with this game. I give 9/10 for Postal 2 and 7.5/10 for Apocalypse Weekend. :)

This game takes everything bad in other games, makes them fun, and absolutely insults those games. Let's get to the simple review parts.  Controls are straightforward. You move with WASD, look with the Mouse, and use various buttons for other commands. Some weapons have an alternate fire, such as throwing scissors or using both barrels of a shotgun, some items require you to aim when thrown, and so on. Standard FPS controls in every regard.  Music is lacking. Greatly. About the only memorable music I can remember is the music heard in the grocery store, which sounds like it's from a parody of Middle-East culture. Of course, that's the whole point, but it's pretty weak in that it's not even that good. Granted, the music would be drowned out by the ambiance and dialogue, but still.  Gameplay is exceptionally fun. You can literally do nothing, or you can go Postal and kill everyone in a variety of ways. One of the more notable and entertaining 'weapons' is your own ♥♥♥♥♥; you unzip your pants, whip it out, and urinate. You can pee all over things, on people's faces, on cats and dogs, and even on a doughnut that a cop is about to eat. Why is this so funny? Because it's disgusting and nasty, and that's absolutely hilarious. There's few points where you can do something other than what's intended, such as running away with milk rather than paying, sending a dog after a cop by letting the cop hit you, killing Gary Coleman and taking his autograph, and my personal favorite; killing everyone at the junkyard and running for dear life from all the angry rednecks and dogs. Insane or Sane, you can play however you like and always get the same ending.  Storyline is slim but enjoyable; you are the Dude, going about your daily life for one week. Collect milk, call your wife a ♥♥♥♥♥, set cars on fire, ♥♥♥♥ on cats, and so on. You know, stuff you do on your normal daily life. It's nothing too grand, nor is it lacking; it's an ordinary man's ordinary day, and nothing more or less.  Unless you're a radical feminist, this game is mindlessly fun. Just let loose in a virtual alternate world, and enjoy yourself. Be an ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ or be a pacifist, be a hero or be a crook. Be the man who waits in line, or be the man who clears a line with a shotgun. You are in control.

---- 10/10 ---- WHY?:  because it does what it is supposed to do, it gives you free choice. You want to wait in a long line and then get ripped off, no problem. You can also just take it by force and go POSTAL.   Difficulties: There are 15 Different ones. On lower ones its pretty similar but the NPC get better weapons the higher it goes. If you put it on POSTAL difficulty it becomes a challengeing shooter, because everyone will attack you when they realize its you.   Weapons: Are wierd, funny and sometimes dont feel like in other shooters. The pistol for example is mostly used for snipeing. The M4 feels really wierd and you often dont really aim. There are also awesome weapons like the sawnoff shotgun, katana, sniperrifle and the infected madcow-head(like a poison gas grenade, rare and powerfull).  Missions: The missions are funny, wierd, politically incorrect or sometimes insane. Most of them sound very easy at first but the game tries the best to make you go postal. You seem to be that guy in the wrong place at the wrong time.  Style: The game is full of bad jokes, dark humor, funny art and references to worldly worries/problems which it makes fun of. If you dont like that style and dont get the jokes or dont want to get them then you will hate the game otherwise its a treasure.  Positive Facts: the game is from 2003 but gets still some updates ( RWS > EA Games) the 'DLC' Paradise Lost is a complete addon that gives you a new week to complete and lots of new content ( RWS > Moneymaking-DLC-Companies) you can complete the game without killing anyone, so if people say its a violent game then its not the game thats violent but the person playing it, right?  If you are easily offended then stay away from this. Other then that have some postaldude quotes: THATS ♥♥♥♥ING AWESOME. MHMMM SMELLS LIKE CHICKEN! I MUST SAY IM PRETTY GOOD AT THIS. HEY ITS NOT MY FAULT BOOK THE KID WITH THE KEYBOARD.

Postal 2 is a simple entertaining game where you play as an average psychopath living his everyday life. It is just another normal day for you as you go about doing errands and killing people who look at you funny. I found joy in being cynical.  Favourite part was stealing equipment from bank robbers who fought the cops while I stole the money from the vault.  Or firing a nuke cannon.  Or charging into fortified compounds high on drugs while wielding the machete.  Or using said machete to attempt to cut off limbs of anybody one by one without killing them while making it a slow torture.  A lot of things to do in this game. Depends on how psychotic and creative you can be.  No worries people against violence. You can attempt to make it through passively. I tried but I hated queues. Oh and loading times are reasonable and it is impossible to get stuck.  Gameplay is good for its time but a more informative tutorial might be nice.  I think of it as Saints row and GTA had a child that was malnulrished and abused to the the point of becoming more psychotic than his folks.  Get it on sale and you will never regret. Ever. Get it full price and you will still say 'Cheaper than GTA'.

I remember 13 year old me watching playthroughs of this game on YouTube. Hoping one day I too could have people be nice to me during lunch. Postal 2 is a very simple game. You start the day in front of your trailer and must finish the simple tasks on your to-do list. What I really like about this game is that you don't actually have to go postal. You can wait in line to buy that milk carton, or you can run and hide like a coward during a bank robbery. The controls are just like any other FPS, WASD to move, space to jump, and the mouse to aim and shoot. The suicide key makes a comeback, it is also on the other side of the key board so you won't accidentally kill yourself as often. There is also a new addition to things that should be in more games, the zipper button. This allows you to showoff your #blackgift and also urinate on anything you could ever hope for. The comedy in this game isn't really its strong suit, at least for me. They mostly revolve around racial and sexual stereotypes. This isn't a game you should play if you want to be president or something of that nature. If you can find this game on sale for under a dollar, you should pick it up.

Let me say first- Postal 2 is an amazing, sprawling game that, while having dated graphics, has aged beautifully over the years, by this point having numerous expansions, great online play and a dedicated group of developers that have continued to breathe life into this timeless classic. That being said, I'll keep it short and sweet. I love this game. Play it for yourself and see what all the hoopla is about, you won't be disappointed.

Short review:   Should you play Postal 2 and Apocalypse Weekend? Totally. Should you play Paradise Lost? Eh. Try it. It's pretty cheap, but I personally was disappointed.  The only thing I don't like in this game is crouch-jumping. But the world isn't built around using it to get to 99% of the places, so whatever.   _____  Long review: The gameplay feels natural, the controls are responsive and you have plenty of guns for various distances between you and your enemies. Also plenty of 'I just wanna mess around' weaponry.   But what I like the most about Postal 2 is the atmosphere. And not the 'kill everyone then ♥♥♥♥ on their corpses' part of it. Sure, it may be fun to test out your arsenal for the first 30 minutes of the game or so, but then you just live out the life of The Dude.  For me, it's just fun to see what mess you can get yourself into. Completely accidentally (well, more like by activating a scripted scene) or on purpose. You just wanted to return a book to the library — now a(nother) group of crazy protestors thinks you are their worst enemy. You were just buying milk and your curiosity made you check out the storage room — oops, the indian taliban (yeah, better not question it) salesguy and his harem now wants you dead. Oh well, where was my shotgun?  Audio is great. There is no ambiance music except for some locations like a nightclub or arcade shop. Instead there are plenty of nature and industrial noises and people talking/killing/exploding, which only improves the feeling of walking around the town in the middle of nowhere. Map music is just awesome. Dude's phrases are great. They fit perfectly and are exactly what you'd expect from this kind of cynical lunatic. There's enough of lines recorded to keep the killing sprees (or just walking around with a petition) interesting.  Now, I should mention sequels. Not counting Postal 3. As far as I know, that 'game' doesn't exist.   Apocalypse Weekend (AW) is great. Two more days of pure mayhem with good humor and alright missions. It's driven by a story, but well paced and has an enjoyable ending. You won't be disappointed.  Paradise Lost is more of Apocalypse Weekend, and, in my opinion, that's bad. As I mentioned with AW, you progress through the story for the sake of progressing through the story. In classic Postal 2 you accomplished the most mundane tasks because you pretty much didn't have anything else to do and it was fun to see what game will throw at you this time. Here you want to see what happens next. But wait, gotta do this errand first! Then another errand, then this errand, then we will let you progress through the plot. Maybe. Everything else in the formula is great, but this one thing ruined it for me so much, I just don't want to finish it.

Postal 2, love it or hate it, is one ballsy game, and I'm not talking about Krotchy. The graphics are very dated, but as far as free roam first person shooters with a urination mechanic go, it's second to none. Now putting the decade plus old game on Steam with full achievement, workshop, and DLC? Brilliant. If the thought of throwing a scythe to cut off a pedestrian's legs, pouring gasoline on them, tossing a lit match to set them on fire, then ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ on them to put them out as they crawl in pain, making other bystanders throw up sounds hilariously over the top, get this game. Also, if the thought of a game where you do simple tasks like buying milk and going to the bank every day for a week sounds fun, go ahead and buy it, too. Fun for the whole family.
